NOTES 
 

The fiscal year (FY) of the Government of Nauru ends on 30 June. “FY” before a calendar 
year denotes the year in which the fiscal year ends, e.g., FY2016 ends on 30 June 2016. 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars unless otherwise stated.

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed grant 
to Nauru for the Sustainable and Climate-Resilient Connectivity Project. The report also describes 
the  proposed  administration  of  grants  to  be  provided  by  the  Government  of  Australia  and  the 
Green Climate Fund (GCF) for the project, and if the Board approves the proposed grant, I, acting 
under the authority delegated to me by the Board, approve the administration of the grants.  
 
The project will build a climate-resilient port in Nauru, including a wharf, a berth pocket, 
2. 
and a breakwater at Aiwo. It will reconstruct port buildings, the container storage area, and port 
security facilities. The project will support institutional reforms to strengthen the Port Authority of 
Nauru  (PAN)  and  achieve  sound  and  efficient  port  governance  and  management.  It  will  also 
establish a revolving fund to ensure financially sustainable port operation and maintenance (O&M).  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

A. 
 
3. 
Fragile economy. Nauru is a single isolated island in the Pacific with a land area of only 
21 square kilometers and a population of 11,288.1  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) identifies 
Nauru  as  a  country  in  fragile  and  conflict-affected  situations  since  2008.2 Nauru’s  economy  is 
highly  volatile  and  based  on diminishing  phosphate  mining, the  sale  of  fishing  rights,  and  a 
regional processing center for migrants seeking asylum in Australia. In the 1970s, Nauru had one 
of  the  highest  rates  of  national  income  per  capita  in  the  world.  By  the  1990s,  however,  the 
economy  had  contracted  severely  as  phosphate  reserves  and  mining  revenue  dried  up.  The 
government introduced broad fiscal and financial management reforms starting in 2005, and the 
economy has recovered. Nauru’s gross domestic product grew at an annual average rate of 5% 
in 2015–2016.3 The country’s phosphate reserves, its main natural resource, have become nearly 
exhausted, and significant economic uncertainties remain. Nauru urgently needs to upgrade its 
infrastructure to quickly develop alternative sources of revenue and growth.   
 
4. 
Aiwo  Port  is  the  only  gateway  for  essential  imports  and  exports.  Nauru  is  almost 
totally dependent on maritime transport for its survival. More than 95% of Nauru’s international 
trade moves by sea. This makes safe and effective maritime port operations critical to meeting its 
people’s basic needs for fuel, medical supplies, food, and water. Shipping operations in and out 
of  Nauru  are  neither  safe,  nor  effective,  nor  year-round.  Aiwo’s  aged  port  infrastructure  is 
dilapidated and was never developed to the standard needed for efficient operations in Nauru’s 
challenging maritime environment. This and the increasingly worsening ocean conditions at Nauru 
now make the port frequently inoperable, with shutdowns often lasting weeks at a time. Nauru is 
plagued by regular fuel, electricity, food, and water shortages. The port’s deficiencies drive up 
shipping rates and the country’s overall basic costs of living. The education and health sectors 
suffer from chronic supply shortages. Rates of lifestyle disease (diabetes and obesity) are among 

                                                 
1   Government  of  Nauru,  National  Bureau  of  Statistics.  http://nauru.prism.spc.int  (assessed  2015).  This  does  not 

include about 1,200 residents of the government’s regional refugee processing center. 

2  ADB. 2012. Working Differently in Fragile and Conflict-Affected Situations: The ADB Experience. Manila. The current  
list of ADB developing member countries identified as fragile and conflict-affected situations is accessible from ADB-
FCAS-List-2007-2016[updated-14-July-2016].docx. 

3  ADB. 2015. Nauru: 2014 Strategic Country Analysis. Manila; ADB. 2017. Pacific Economic Monitor. Manila. 
 

 

  

2 

the highest in the Pacific. About a quarter of the population lives below the country’s basic-needs 
poverty line.4 
 
5. 
Inoperability and dangers of the current port facilities and operations. The existing 
Aiwo  Port  consists  of  a  small  boat  harbor  built  in  1907,  an  offshore  anchorage  and  mooring 
system, a container yard, and the PAN buildings.5 It cannot accommodate oceangoing containers 
and cargo ships, which are forced to load and unload their cargoes beyond the fringing reef in 
deep open waters. All cargo and container transfers onto and off the vulnerable pusher barges 
that run back and forth between the vessels and the boat harbor dock are done manually. This is 
difficult, time-consuming, and dangerous to crews and vessels. Fuel, freight, and demurrage costs 
are far higher than they should be because each loading and unloading takes an average of 21 
days to complete. 
 
6. 
The cargo transfers on the open sea and safe transit for the small barges are impossible 
when  the  weather  and  the  speed  and  direction  of  wind  are  unfavorable.  The  mooring  system 
meant  to  secure  ocean  ships  offshore  is  often  damaged  during  harsh  conditions  and  out  of 
operation for months until costly repairs can be done. This means visiting ships must offload while 
adrift on the ocean near the reef.6 When the sea is too rough, work stops. The port must shut 
down completely for 3 months a year. 

 
The existing port buildings are in danger of collapse, contain asbestos, pose serious safety 
7. 
risks for PAN workers, have capacity limitations, and do not comply with International Ship and 
Port Facility Security requirements.7  

 
PAN faces multiple port management challenges. The port operations are not financially 
8. 
viable. Tariff levels do not reflect the cost of delivering the services the port provides. PAN lacks 
technical and managerial capacity and formal management systems.  

 
Port  vulnerabilities  intensifying  with  climate  change.  Aiwo  is  extremely  exposed  to 
9. 
westerly winds. Use of the small barges to ferry cargo and containers in and out of the shallow 
boat harbor has become more and more difficult, dangerous, and prone to prolonged delays and 
shutdowns. Climate analysis and PAN records show that westerly waves of more than 2 meters 
in height, which disrupt port operations offshore for at least 3 months a year, have become more 
frequent. Westerly waves and swells are driven by the El Niňo Southern Oscillation, the South 
Pacific Convergence Zone, the Western Pacific Monsoon, and distant tropical cyclonic activities. 
A  climate  risk  and  vulnerability  assessment  indicates  significant  risks  that  climate  change  will 
intensify the effects of these climate drivers.8 Worsening waves, winds, and long-range cyclones, 
along with rising sea levels, will make the current port facilities inoperable for longer periods every 
year in the future.   
 

                                                 
4  Government of Nauru. 2013. Nauru Hardship and Poverty Report. Nauru.  
5  Government of Nauru. 2015. Nauru Port Pre-Feasibility Study by Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility. Nauru. The 
small walled harbor on the east coast at Anibare is used mainly by fishing vessels, although containers are sometimes 
ferried  into  its  dock  from  offshore  ships  when  operations  at  Aiwo  are  shut  down  by  seasonal  heavy  seas  on  the 
western side of the island. Port development at Anibare has been discounted because the (i) area is exposed to 
trade winds and wave climate for about 9 months of the year; (ii) the subsea geology comprises a submarine landslip, 
presenting a significant risk that further subsea instability may severely damage new port infrastructure; (iii) the reef 
and marine ecosystem around and within Anibare Bay is relatively pristine, and any port development would place 
this ecosystem at high risk of irreversible damage. 

6   Maintenance of the mooring system costs the government an average of A$1 million a year.  
7   International Maritime Organization. 2003. Code of Practice on Security in Ports. Geneva. 
8   Climate Change Assessment (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 3 

Nauru’s sea link shrinking and imperiled. Historically, two shipping lines—Neptune and 
10. 
Matson  Shipping—have  served  Nauru.  In  November  2015,  the  chronic  delays,  technical 
challenges,  added  expense,  and  risks  of  using  the  inadequate,  unprotected  port  at  Aiwo  led 
Matson Shipping to suspend its service to the country. This has left Neptune the only shipping 
company still willing to operate in Nauru. Dependence on a single line increases the country’s 
shipping costs, consumer prices, and vulnerability. With climatic, weather, and sea conditions at 
Aiwo expected to worsen, the risk that Neptune Shipping will also withdraw its vessels one day is 
high.  This  would  force  the  government  to  charter  ships  at  even  higher  costs  simply  to  keep 
Nauru’s lifeline open. 

 
11. 
In 2010–2012, an average of 19 container vessels and eight fuel ships visited Nauru each 
year. During this period, the port handled an annual average of 1,415 twenty-foot equivalent units 
of container shipments and 18 phosphate ships. In 2013, after the regional processing center for 
asylum  seekers  reopened,  container  ship  arrivals  rose  significantly  from  18  to  32,  and  the 
container shipment volume more than doubled to 2,856 twenty-foot equivalent units. Ship arrivals 
dropped in 2016 after Matson Shipping withdrew its services (para. 10). If current port conditions 
persist,  the  decline  in  ship  visits  and  container  volume  is  projected  to  continue.  But  once  the 
proposed project completes the improvement of port facilities and reforms of port operations, pre-
2012 levels are expected to be restored and possibly surpassed by 2020.  

 
Options  studied  for  improving  the  port.  Nauru’s  geography  is  uniquely  hostile  to 
12. 
maritime  shipping  and  offers  few  options  for  developing  adequate  berthing  facilities  for 
oceangoing  ships.  It  has  no  natural  harbor,  and  the  seabed  drops  sharply  just  beyond  the 
surrounding  reef,  reaching  3,000  meters  (or  3  kilometers)  in  depth  within  7  kilometers  of  the 
coastline. Alternatives for the design of a protected port are further limited by the westerly waves 
and swells at Aiwo (para. 9). Several organizations conducted studies on the best way to provide 
Nauru  with  an  efficient,  effective,  and  reliable  port—ADB  in  2009, 9  the  Japan  International 
Cooperation Agency in 2014,10 and the Pacific Region Infrastructure Facility in 2015 (footnote 5). 
ADB  performed  two  additional  studies  for  the  project  in  2015–2017.11 Together,  these  studies 
explored  21  designs  and  exhausted  virtually  every  technically  feasible  option.  The  proposed 
project design includes the construction of a 170-meter-long, 30-meter-wide wharf adjacent to a 
50-meter-wide berth pocket dredged into the reef; a breakwater about 140 meters long; and port 
building and security facilities. The design is technically feasible, complies with International Ship 
and Port Facility Security requirements, and ensures climate resilience. This is also the least-cost 
option. 
 
Readiness for implementation. The project is at a high level of implementation readiness. 
13. 
The due diligence was completed with project preparatory transaction technical assistance (TA) 
(footnote 11). ADB’s project design advance (PDA) prepared the detailed engineering design and 
bidding documents (footnote 11). The project preparatory TA completed a detailed assessment 
of  the  needs  for  institutional  strengthening  and  capacity  building  (port  reforms)  at  PAN.  The 
Government of Australia has already provided a A$3.3 million grant to support the port reforms, 
which will be implemented under the TA (footnote 11).  
 
Value added by ADB assistance. ADB led the efforts by Nauru’s development partners 
14. 
to help the government achieve its critical goal of developing Aiwo Port. The GCF board agreed 
                                                 
9   Government of Nauru. 2009. Nauru Port Development Scoping Study Final Report. Consultant’s report. Nauru. 
10 Japan International Cooperation Agency. 2014. The Preparatory Study on the Project of Constructing Reef-Edge 

Quay Wall and Causeway at Aiwo Harbor. Tokyo. 

11 ADB. 2015. Project Design Advance: Nauru Port Development Project. Manila; ADB. 2015. Technical Assistance to 

Nauru for the Nauru Port Development Project. Manila. 

 

 

  

4 

Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 

to cofinance the project, approving ADB’s funding proposal at its meeting on 2 October 2017 (para. 
22). ADB has been instrumental in designing the reforms to restructure PAN (para. 24). It also 
spearheaded  the  work  to  set  up  a  revolving  O&M  fund  to  ensure  that  port  operations  and 
maintenance of the new assets are sustainable beyond project completion (para. 25).  
 
15. 
The  project  promotes  poverty  reduction,  inclusive  economic  growth,  climate  resilience, 
and infrastructure development in a small state facing fragile and conflict-affected situations. This 
is consistent with the government’s priorities12 and aligned with ADB’s Pacific Approach, 2016–
2020.13 The project is also aligned with ADB’s Midterm Review of Strategy 2020.14 
 
B. 
 
The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impact:  sustainability  and  quality  of  life  of  all 
16. 
Nauruans  improved. 15 The  project  will  have  the  following  outcome:  efficiency,  reliability,  and 
climate resilience of Aiwo Port improved.16   
 
C. 
 
17. 
Output 1: Climate-proofed port infrastructure constructed. The project will construct 
new port infrastructure, including a wharf, a berth pocket, and a breakwater. It will also reconstruct 
port buildings, the container storage area, and port security facilities.  
 
18. 
Output  2:  Sustainable  operations  and  maintenance  achieved.  Supported  by  the 
ongoing TA, the government will set up a revolving fund to be used exclusively to finance the 
maintenance of the assets constructed under the project.17 The fund will be built initially to cover 
3  years  of  maintenance  costs.  It  will  be  financed  by  port  revenue  and  government  budget 
allocations. The government contribution will decline over time as the port, supported by reforms, 
gradually achieves positive operating net income. This is expected by June 2021 (paras. 25 and 
30.  
 
19. 
Output 3: Efficient port operations established. Under the ongoing TA, the government 
and PAN will carry out port reforms, including institutional strengthening, capacity development, 
tariff restructuring, and the engagement of the private sector in port operations and management 
(para. 24).  

 
Summary Cost Estimates and Financing Plan 

D. 
 
20. 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $79.59  million  (Table  1).  Detailed  cost  estimates  by 
expenditure category and by financier are provided in the project administration manual (PAM).18 
The  port  reforms  will  be  undertaken  in  parallel  with  project  implementation  and  financed 
separately by the TA (footnote 11). Its associated costs are summarized in the TA paper. The 
detailed engineering services were provided through ongoing PDA (footnote 11). 

                                                 
12  Government of Nauru. 2005. Nauru Sustainable Development Strategy 2005–2025. Nauru. 
13  ADB. 2016. Pacific Approach, 2016–2020. Manila. The Pacific Approach acts as the country partnership strategy for 

Nauru, as approved by ADB’s vice-president of operations 2 on 1 July 2011.  

14  ADB. 2014. Midterm Review of Strategy 2020: Meeting the Challenges of a Transforming Asia and Pacific. Manila. 
15 Government  of  Nauru.  2005.  Nauru  Sustainable  Development  Strategy  2005–2025.  Nauru;  Pacific  Region 

Infrastructure Facility.  2011. Nauru Economic Infrastructure Strategy and Investment Plan. Nauru. 

16 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
17 Grant Agreement: Asian Development Fund (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
18  Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

Source: Asian Development Bank estimates.

 
21. 
The government has requested a grant not exceeding $21.30 million from ADB’s Special 
Funds  resources  (Asian  Development  Fund)  to  help  finance  the  project.  The  government  will 
provide  counterpart  financing  in  the  amount  of  $17.30  million  and  has  committed  to  fund  any 
shortfall  in  the  project  finances.  The  government  has  also  requested  grants  not  exceeding 
A$18.00 million ($14.08 million equivalent) from the Government of Australia and $26.91 million 
from the GCF, both to be administered by ADB, to help finance the project. The disbursement of 
ADB financing and ADB-administered cofinancing will be on a cost-sharing basis and front-loaded 
against the government counterpart financing. The summary financing plan is in Table 2.

Climate change adaptation costs. Of the overall $79.59 million project costs, the cost of 
22. 
climate  change  adaptation  is  estimated  to  be  $54.87  million.  This  cost  is  calculated  as  the 
difference between the costs of the port development options with and without climate resilience. 
The  without-climate  resilience  option  involves  strengthening  the  existing  open-sea  mooring 
system. The with-climate resilience option involves the breakwater, dredging to enable ships to 
safely enter and berth in the calmer waters that the breakwater will protect, and a wharf for loading 

 

 

  

6 

Implementation Arrangements 

and  unloading.  The  selected  option  is  the  most  cost-effective  of  the  feasible  alternatives  for 
providing climate resilience. The GCF will fund about half of the adaptation costs (49%).  
 
E. 
 
23. 
A project steering committee comprising representatives of line ministries and chaired by 
the secretary, Ministry of Finance (MOF) will provide overall oversight. MOF will be the executing 
agency, and PAN the implementing agency. A project management unit (PMU) to be established 
will include PAN staff and supervision consultants. PAN’s chief executive officer, to be recruited 
internationally, will be responsible for the project’s supervision and day-to-day implementation, 
including  financial  management,  monitoring,  and  evaluation.  The  PMU  will  maintain  separate 
accounts  for  the  project,  which  will  be  audited  by  an  independent  auditor.  The  PMU  will  be 
responsible  for  procuring  the  civil  works  contract  under  ADB  oversight.  The  government  has 
delegated the selection of supervision consultants to ADB.  
 
24. 
The project team will carry out the port reforms under the ongoing TA alongside project 
implementation (footnote 11). The reforms will strengthen PAN, introduce legislative amendments 
for  organizational  and  port  tariff  restructuring,  create  an  effective  asset  management  system, 
establish a revolving fund for O&M, and engage a private sector port operator to ensure long-term 
sustainability of assets. The government will implement the reforms from 1 January 2018 to 31 
December 2022.    
 
25. 
The government will set up and maintain the revolving fund for port maintenance during 
the  implementation  of  port  reforms  from  1  July  2018  to  30  June  2023.  Since  Nauru’s  banking 
system consists of a single banking agency, the fund will likely be deposited in a bank in Australia. 
It will be used as the new port becomes operational by June 2020 and replenished annually to 
ensure  that it  can  cover  3  years  of  maintenance  costs.  The  implementation  arrangements  are 
summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the PAM (footnote 18).

 7 

Aspects 
Retroactive financing and/or 
advance contractingb 

Disbursement  

Arrangements

Retroactive financing for the reimbursement of eligible expenditures 
incurred under the project before the effective date of the grant 
agreements, up to a maximum amount equivalent to 20% of each 
grant amount. Such expenditures cannot have been incurred more 
than 12 months before the date of signing of the grant agreements. 
Advance contracting for consulting services and civil works will be 
carried out. The government has delegated the recruitment of 
consultants to ADB.
ADB and ADB-administered grant proceeds will be disbursed following 
ADB's Loan Disbursement Handbook (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and detailed arrangements agreed between the government and 
ADB.  

ADB = Asian Development Bank. 
a  Includes physical and price contingencies. 
b   Retroactive financing under the Green Climate Fund (GCF) grant will only be upon written permission from GCF. 
If GCF does not approve, the retroactive financing will be allocated to ADB and the Government of Australia on 
a proportional basis. 

Source: Asian Development Bank and Government of Nauru Ministry of Finance. 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

A. 
 
26. 
Design features. The project team, through the TA and PDA, assessed all the technically 
feasible  options.  These  assessments  included  wave  analysis;  the  testing  of  infrastructure 
configurations  through  ship  simulation  modeling;  geotechnical  investigations;  topographic, 
cadastral, and bathymetric surveys; and an assessment of the presence of unexploded ordnance 
within  the  proposed  development  footprint.  The  project  team  closely  considered  construction 
issues, wave climate and climate change impacts, berthing availability, and wharf orientation. The 
breakwater, wharf, foreshore port buildings, and container yard have been designed for greater 
heights to withstand projected rises in sea levels and increasing severity and frequency of waves. 
These design features add to the project’s climate resilience and economic viability.     
 
Climate  change  adaptation  measures.  The  project’s  main  climate  change  adaptation 
27. 
measures—dredging  a  berthing  pocket  and  constructing  the  wharf  and  breakwater—will  cost 
$54.87 million. Of this, the GCF is providing $26.91 million in grant cofinancing. These measures 
will enable oceangoing vessels serving Nauru to berth in an area protected from climatic hazards 
and  climate  change  effects,  and  to  transfer  cargo  and  containers  directly  to  and  from  land 
alongside a sheltered wharf.  

 
28. 
Climate  change  mitigation  measures.  Climate  change  mitigation  will  be  achieved  by 
 Once the project 
reducing the emission of greenhouse gases, particularly carbon dioxide (CO2).
is completed, fuel-powered pusher barges will no longer be needed to ferry shipments to and from 
vessels offshore. The average berthing stay of a container ship is expected to decline from about 
21 days to 3 days once the new facilities are built. Fuel ship berthing should be cut to 1 day on 
average  from  the  current  4  days.  Shorter  berthing  periods  and  elimination  of  the  need  for 
motorized barges will significantly reduce the fuel consumed by port operations and cut emissions 
by  an  estimated  10,708  tons  of  CO2  a  year.  Because  ship  visits  are  expected  to  marginally 
increase (para. 11), the project is projected to reduce CO2 emissions by about 500,000 tons over 
its 50-year economic lifetime.  
 

 

 

  

8 

Economic and Financial 

B. 
 
29. 
The project’s primary quantifiable benefits are (i) savings in time and operating costs for 
visiting cargo and fuel vessels, (ii) costs saved by eliminating the need for pusher barges to ferry 
cargo,  (iii)  savings  afforded  by  eliminating  the  need  to  charter  shipping  vessels  to  keep  the 
maritime lifeline open, (iv) reduced  port operation costs thanks to shorter berthing periods per 
vessel,  and  (v)  savings  from  climate  change  mitigation  thanks  to  reduced  greenhouse  gas 
emissions. The project is economically viable, with an estimated economic internal rate of return 
of 9.4%. A sensitivity analysis applying a worst-case scenario of a 10% drop in benefits and a 
10% rise in construction costs from the baseline case shows that the project would still yield an 
economic internal rate of return of 7.3%. This would be acceptable given the project’s substantial 
unquantified benefits, including a reduction in damage to perishable imports, increase in safety 
and security at the port (fewer accidents), and social benefits.     

Governance 

 
30. 
The project is financially viable with an estimated financial internal rate of return of 2.9%, 
which  is  higher  than  the  weighted  average  cost  of  capital  of  1.3%.  This  assumes,  however,  a 
substantial increase in the port handling tariff, as approved by the government. The introduction 
of  higher  tariffs  underwent  intensive  stakeholder  consultations.  In  November  2017,  the 
government gazetted the law to increase the tariffs. Therefore, the risk of not implementing the 
tariff increase is moderate. Nevertheless, to mitigate the risks and ensure financial sustainability, 
the government agreed to set up a dedicated maintenance fund earmarked from its budget from 
1 July 2018. This fund will fully cover port operations and maintenance if the project does not 
generate sufficient revenue (para. 18). The port reforms will recommend appropriate management 
of any accumulated funds generated from the port tariffs.  
 
C. 
 
31. 
Reforms  for  efficiency  and  sustainability.  The  project  will  support  comprehensive 
reforms to improve the port’s performance and secure its long-term sustainability (para. 24). Once 
the new port is operational, the government will engage a qualified private sector operator to run 
the port. This will reduce operating costs and improve port efficiency.  
 
Financial management risks and mitigation measures. The financial management risk 
32. 
is rated high at PAN. This is mainly because of PAN’s lack of experience in managing externally 
funded  projects.  Among  other  things,  the  mitigation  measures  supported  by  the  TA  will  (i) 
strengthen  PAN  institutionally  and  develop  its  capacity;  (ii)  establish  a  financial  management 
information system and accounting procedures; (iii) ensure the adoption of an asset management 
and  maintenance  plan,  and  the  establishment  of  the  revolving  maintenance  fund;  (iv)  draft 
legislative amendments for organizational and tariff restructuring and regulations to be passed by 
31 December 2019; (v) engage experienced international experts for key positions in PAN; and 
(vi) provide on-the-job and overseas training for PAN staff.  
 
33. 
Procurement and implementation risks and mitigation measures. ADB will disburse 
funds directly to contractors, consultants, and suppliers engaged by the project, which now boasts 
high  procurement  readiness  thanks  to  PDA  support  (para.  13).  ADB  will  supervise  the 
procurement  of  works  and  goods  and  the  selection  of  consultants.  It  will  closely  monitor  the 
performance of contractors, consultants, and suppliers. PAN will prepare regular financial reports 
and engage an external auditor acceptable to ADB to prepare annual audited financial statements. 
All  project-related  expenses  will  be  disbursed  following  ADB’s  Loan  Disbursement  Handbook 
(2017, as amended from time to time). 
 

 

 9 

Safeguards 

Poverty, Social, and Gender 

ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
34. 
with  the  government,  MOF,  and  PAN.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM.  
 
D. 
 
35. 
The project will benefit the entire Nauru population. A reliable year-round port will provide 
access  to  essential  imported  goods  that  are  now  increasingly  difficult  and  expensive  for  the 
country to obtain. These include staple goods; fresh produce and more nutritious foods; medicines 
and medical supplies (which are now often delayed, damaged, or lost in transit); and education 
materials and equipment. As maritime freight costs decline, the quarter of the population currently 
living below the basic-needs poverty line will be able to better afford consumer goods.  
 
36. 
The project is categorized effective gender mainstreaming. PAN currently employs only 
three women on its staff of 60. PAN will implement a gender action plan that will significantly boost 
participation by women and contribute to their economic empowerment. The plan sets minimum 
targets for female participation in community consultations, project committees, PAN’s skilled and 
unskilled workforce, training for communities, and on the PMU staff.    
 
E. 
 
37. 
categories are as follows.19 
 
Environment  (category  B).  The  initial  environmental  examination  confirms  that  the 
38. 
project  will  have  no  significant  impacts  on  the  environment  since  it  will  be  undertaken  largely 
within  the  footprint  of  the  existing  port  facilities.  The  project  team  has  updated  the  initial 
environmental examination, including the environmental management plan (EMP), based on the 
detailed design. The project will not impact any endemic, endangered, or significant marine or 
terrestrial  biodiversity  and  will  not  affect  freshwater,  forests,  and  agriculture.  Impacts  on  the 
terrestrial and shallow water marine ecosystems and their environments are expected to be minor 
and can be managed through mitigation measures. The EMP will guide the contractor in preparing 
the construction EMP, which must be reviewed and cleared by the PMU and ADB before physical 
activities begin. 
 
39. 
Involuntary  resettlement  (category  C).  The  project  will  be  implemented  within  the 
existing port land parcel, which the government has been leasing since 1907. The project will not 
result  in  physical  or  economic  displacement  or  involuntary  resettlement.  The  project  team 
prepared a due diligence report to confirm land ownership and ensure that the land lease and 
arrangements comply with government laws and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. All the key 
stakeholders have been consulted and will continue to be consulted during implementation.  

 In  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009),  the  project’s  safeguard 

 
Indigenous peoples (category C). No indigenous peoples live on the island who can be 

40. 
defined as distinct and vulnerable. 
 

                                                 
19  ADB. Safeguard Categories. https://www.adb.org/site/safeguards/safeguard-categories. 
 

 

 

  

10 

Summary of Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan 

F. 
 
41. 
The overall project risk is high, based on the current circumstances at PAN. Significant 
risks  and  mitigating  measures  are  summarized  in  Table  4  and  described  in  detail  in  the  risk 
assessment and risk management plan.20 
 

Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 

Risks 
Port operations and project implementation 
are inefficient because of weak PAN and 
PMU capacity.  

PAN’s financial management is ad hoc. PAN 
does not have an acceptable financial 
management system. 
 

Cost overruns may occur if substantial hard 
materials and unexploded ordnance are 
found during construction. 
Future extreme climate change events that 
exceed projections lead to unanticipated 
closure of the improved port.  

Mitigation Measures
The project will support comprehensive port reforms 
and strengthen capacity development of PAN. The 
government will provide at least six full-time staff 
members to the PMU. PAN’s chief executive will chair 
the PMU, who will be engaged throughout the port 
reforms.
The project will implement a complete overhaul of, and 
reforms to, PAN’s financial management system, 
introduce acceptable financial management processes 
and procedures, and procure a suitable financial 
management information system. 
Sufficient contingencies are provided for this under the 
project and will be included in the port construction 
contract.
The detailed design includes climate-resilient solutions 
to mitigate future extreme weather situations. PAN 
revenue will be used for additional improvement of the 
port assets to manage future extreme climate change 
events beyond projections.

PAN = Port Authority of Nauru, PMU = project management unit. 
Source: Asian Development Bank and the Government of Nauru. 

IV. 

ASSURANCES AND CONDITIONS 

42. 
The  government  and  PAN  have  assured  ADB  that  implementation  of  the  project  shall 
conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies,  including  those  concerning  anticorruption,  safeguards, 
gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail in the PAM 
and grant agreements. 
 
43. 
which are set forth in the draft grant agreements and project agreement. 

The government and PAN have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 

 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

44. 
I am satisfied that the proposed grant would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the grant not exceeding 
$21,300,000 to Nauru from ADB’s Special Funds resources (Asian Development Fund) for the 
Sustainable  and  Climate-Resilient  Connectivity  Project,  on  terms  and  conditions  that  are 
substantially  in  accordance  with  those  set  forth  in  the  draft  grant  and  project  agreements 
presented to the Board. 

 

 

 

 
15 December 2017
                                                 
20 Risk Assessment and Risk Management Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

  

 

 

 

 

Takehiko Nakao 
President
